And it is to vnderstond þat þis is wont to availe aboue al oþer þing&yogh;: Recipe Iuyse of plantane, muscilage dragaunte & gumme arabic; be þai medled to-gidre, and o party be take be þe mouþe and anoþer be cast in by a clistery; and be þis continued, and without dout it schal cure perfitely, vniuersale purgacions goyng afore, after barnard gordon.  Also corall brent and gumme arabic, y-medled and y-dronke with cold watre, streyneþ þe flux of blode, of what place so-euer it floweþ.  Also cane&llbar; haþe þis propirte, Item cinnamomum habet hanc proprietatem, þat if þer be take of it to þe we&yogh;t of 2 penys eueryday with cold water, it streyneþ at þe best þe flux of emoroides & of menstrue&yogh;.  And if þe forseid poudre be giffen with watre of plantane it schal be more effectual.  Also vitriol, i.[e.] coprose, streyneþ þe flux cum succo tapsibarbato of emeroides and drieþ humours, if it be made with Iuyse of moleyn, or of plantayne, or verueyn, or rubarbe, i.[e.] sengrene; ffor why; of þe medlyng of þe iuyse of any of þe forseid cold herbes þe hete of þe vitriol is repressed; wherfor it constreyneþ with drine&yogh;.  Bot it is to wytte þat þe emoroide&yogh; hid with-in þe lure sine corrosione longanonis & ejusdem fissurâ. ful seldome bene made without fretyng of longaon or kynnyng "cleuyng" of it, And þerfor certaynly sich maner emoroyde&yogh; may no&yogh;t perfitely be cured bot with a medicyne cauteri&yogh;atiue, as is vitriol combuste be it self or medled with quick-lyme, in a grete case, þat is in a grete fretyng.  Also puluis sine pari in þis case putte in heleþ wele, bot disesily or angerfully; bot þat is no&yogh;t to charge. sed de hoc non est notandum . ffor to a strong sekene&yogh; answereþ a strong medicyne, and namely in strong men. I calle, forsoþ, delicate men feble men.  ffor al þing&yogh; bene hard to a waik hert man.  To a strong hert man, forsoþ, is noþing grete. To emoroide&yogh; hid within þe lure, wheþer þai be with fretyng or clyffyng or without, þe most noble cure schal be ich day to caste in in maner of clistre, or ich oþer day, al medicyne&yogh; temperatly liquide in substance with a schort and no maner streit nastar of tre. And do þe lech þis boldely, for þer is no perile þer-in.  ffor why; I haue proued þis ful oft tyme&yogh; for to be most sone helpyng.  Þe fleobotomy y-done, be þer putte vpon of valence or some oþer equiualent medicyne, and be þer done fomentacions and enoyntyngs vnto þe bolnyng&yogh; and þe akyng&yogh; vtterly defaile.  If þe leche, forsoþ, may no&yogh;t wirk þus, make he þe pacient for to be fleobotomed of þe vtter veyne&yogh; of þe legge&yogh; in the euyng as it is seid afore.  Also if þe leche se any men haue aboute þe lure without rounde bolnyng&yogh;, in þe ende&yogh; "heuede&yogh;" of which appereþ blak spotte&yogh;, witte he þan for certayn þat in þam is blak cluttered "coagulate" blode; which forsoþ yknowen, be þer done fomentacions and enoyntyng&yogh;. And afterward tarye no&yogh;t þe leche for to opne with a launcet þe forseid bolnyng&yogh; in þe place of þe blaknes— þe pacient no&yogh;t wittyng—ffor þe pacient schal fele no greuance þer-of; I haue proued it forsoþe oft-tymc&yogh;, And with þis cure al-on I haue sene ful many for to haue be cured for euermore, and þat ri&yogh;t sone.  ¶ And be þe lech war þat none of þam þat standeþ about perceyue when he opneþ with þe lancet or sich oþer þing sich maner bolnyng&yogh;. ffor if barbours knowe þis doyng þai wold vsurpe þis cure, appropriand it to þamself vnto vnworschip and no&yogh;t litel harme of maystre&yogh;.  ¶ If any man, forsoþ, haue as it war purse&yogh; pendentes instar uvæ marcidæ. aboute þe lure withoute, hyngyng in maner of a welked gri[pe], which ar wont for to bifalle of inflacion and ouer miche extension of emoroides had afore; þan if þe pacient consent þe lech may without perile kutte away with a lancet or a rasour al þo burse&yogh;, first y-bond with a þrede, and afterward sone hele þam with vnguento arabico.
4: 16. Of þenasmon & rhagade&yogh; and of þe cure of þam.

16. And for þat þai þat haþe þe emoroides haþe ofttyme a sekene&yogh; þat is called tenasmon, þerfor here we make mencion þer-of.  Tenasmon is a sekene&yogh; within þe lure þat makeþ þe pacient for to desire purgyng of his womb byneþ-forþ; ffor it semeþ hym euermore þat he mi&yogh;t haue egestion, and when he comeþ to þe priuè he may no&yogh;t haue egestion.

¶ Cause of þis seknes bene som tyme emoroides hid within þe lure, or pustule&yogh;, or excoriacions in longaon, or for chynnyngs of longaon vel propter fissuras longanoni. which ar called ragadie, or for hote humour imbibed in longaon, or for þat cold humour is inuistate þer, or for aposteme&yogh;, or for vlcere&yogh;, or for takyng of laxatiue medicyne. Signe&yogh; of hote cause in thenasmon bene hotene&yogh;, brennyng, and prikkyng.  Signe&yogh; of coldne&yogh; is þat cold is feled in þat place, and it is helpid of hotene&yogh;.
¶ If it be for apostemes, þer is grete akyng & greuous.

¶ And if it be for vlcere&yogh;, þer is gret akyng when any-þing is putte þer-in.  And if it be for emoroide&yogh;, þer appereþ bolnyng and inflacion and akyng in þe veyne&yogh; þat ar about þe circle of þe lure.  And if it be for fece&yogh;, it is knowen forþi þat þe pacient long tyme afore went no&yogh;t to sege.
¶ And if it be for medicine laxatiue, it is knowen for þer was in it Diagredium or scamonie or pulpa coloquintidis or aloe.
¶ And if it be for outward cause, it is knowen by schewyng of þe pacient.

¶ Pronosticacion is þis: If þat þe thenasmon last long, it bringeþ to þe colik and iliaca passion, and to vnslepyng and feblenes of vertu, and malice of þolyng, and to passions of þe heued, and to swownyng. And cause of þise is continuel akyng.
¶ If it be for outward cause, Sitte þe pacient in ane hote bath of swete watre with oleo laurino and sich oþer hote apertyue&yogh;. et similibus calidis aperitivis .

¶ And if it be for aposteme and þe bodye be plettorik, be þer made fleobotomye of basilica; And if þe apostems be hote, be þer made clisterie&yogh; of iuyse of endyue, scariole, coriandre, oile of rose and white of an ey.  After þat þe sekene&yogh; haþ proceded, be þer added to þise henne&yogh; grese fresch, and þe dusty "flying" meel of þe milne, and a litel hony. And al þise be giffen leuke in acte. et omnia ista dentur actu tepida . And if þe aposteme be cold fro þe bigynnyng, be þer made ane oyntment of þe iuse of apii and oile of rose, and camamille, and branne, and iuse of caule&yogh;. After þat þe sekenes haþe proceded, be þer added to fenigreke and linnesede, and be þai ministred euermore hote in acte.

¶ Witte þou þat in thenasmon þer is noþing more profitable þan &yogh;ettyng in by a clistery of gote&yogh; mylke; And if þou haue no&yogh;t gote&yogh; mylke, tak cow mylk, and put þer-to a subtile whete meel, and boile þam togidre in maner of children pappe; adde þer-to þe raw &yogh;olk of an ey in þe decoccion, and a litel fresch schepe&yogh; grece after þe liquefaccion, and cole it, and putte in hote bi a clisterie; þis, forsoþ, is mych mitigatyue.
¶ Also þe &yogh;olk of a raw ey tempered with bole armoniac to sich þikknes þat it may by a clistery be &yogh;ette into þe lure, ceseþ at þe best thenasmon;  and þis haue I proued oft tyme&yogh;.
¶ If tenasmon be for ragadias i.[e.] chynnyng&yogh; "cleuyng" within þe lure, cure þe ragadias and thenasmon schal be cured.

¶ A remedie agayn&yogh; thenasmon of what euery cause it be, after Bernard of Gordon, capito de thenasmo&nmacr;; Recipe fenigrec, semen lini, malue bismalue, camamille, mellilote, i.[e.] þe croppe&yogh; of caule&yogh;, ana; be þai brissed and boiled in watre vnto mene þikkene&yogh;, and be it coled, and be it warme cast in by a litel clistery.  ffor, for certane, outward fomentacions and suffumigacions profiteþ no&yogh;t so mych as medicyne&yogh; putte in by a clistery, and þat haue I oftyme proued.

¶ Agayn&yogh; greuous ychyng and vnsuffrable in þe lure take þe iuyse of celydome, chelidon. of moleyne, ana, hony scomyd als mych as of þe iuyse&yogh;, and boile þam togidre to þe wastyng of þe iuyse&yogh;; after sette it downe fro þe fyre and kepe to vse.  When þou wilt vse þer-of agayn&yogh; ychyng, tak þer-of als mych as þou wilt and putte þer-to of puluis of vitriol combuste and alum combuste and orpment, and if nede be boile it agayne vnto it be ane vntement haldyng fast yno&yogh;, and putte a litel þer-of into þe lure agayn&yogh; þe ychyng, and sone it schal cese, and in euery party of þe body for certay[n].  And þis oyntment is called tapsimel, of tapsibarbasti "moleyn" & melle "hony" ; fforsoþe þis is a noble oyntment.

¶ Ragadias may we no&yogh;t cure bot if we bryng in medicyne&yogh; within þe lure, ouþer with clistery or with suppository; ffor medicyne&yogh; putte without-forþe profiteþ ouþer litel or no&yogh;t.  Wherfor first it byhoueþ for to wirch with corrosiue&yogh; to þe mundifiyng, and afterward with consolidatyue&yogh; and desiccatiue&yogh;, as it is seid afore of þe emoroides hid within þe lure.

¶ Agayn&yogh; ragadias, after maister Richard in micrologio suo, Recipe oile made of eiren, or oile of rose, & white of ane ey raw, and iuyse of lyuane, et succo lucasiæ & cimbalarie "pennyworte" ana; medle þam togidre & put þam in.

¶ Agayn&yogh; ragadias within þe lure be made sich ane oyntment after Gilbertus; Recipe oile of rose and of violettes ana ounce ij gote&yogh; or schepe&yogh; talow ounce iss.  be þai al molten togidre at þe fire, and sette þam doune, and moue it continuly with a spature; and when it is almost cold putte in puluer of R. triasantalorum ounce ss. and medle hem togidre; it heleþ wonderfully.
¶ Also oile of linsede putte in availed agayn&yogh; þe forseid sekene&yogh;; it is forsoþ ri&yogh;t desiccatyue.
5: 17. Of goyng out of þe lure & þe cure þere—of.

17. Agayn&yogh; goyng out of þe lure: If vertu and age suffre be þer fyrst y-done fleobotomy of þe vtter sophene of þe legge; Afterward be þer done suffumigacion or fomentacion of ga&llbar;, or of þe rynde of a grene oke or dry; of þe rynde of pome-granate þat is called psidia, and of þe floure&yogh; of granate þat ar called balaustia; of þe rote of camfery decocte in rayne watre.  And if it be in somer þise may be added to, or elle&yogh; by þam selfe: verueyne, moleyne, plantane, gawel, myrrha psillium, iuyse of coriandre, berberi&yogh;, porcelane, bursa pastoris, rede rose, tanesey, wormode, horsmynt, and sich oþer stiptike&yogh;. ¶ Of þise of which þou may haue best make ane hote fomentyng with rayne or rynnyng watre, vinegre added þerto; And after þe fomentyng be sprenkled aboue puluis of bole, of sanguis draconis, of herte&yogh; horne combuste, bark-duste, psidie, balaustie, mumme and sich like. ¶ Afterward, if it may be done on any maner, be þe longaon putte into his place, and be it fast bondyn with warlyne&yogh; ligetur cum cautela . þat it go no&yogh;t out. Also agayn&yogh; goyng out of þe lure be it fomented with watre of decoction of caule&yogh;, and after anoynt it with aloe and vnguentum vetus broken togidre. ¶ Also agayn&yogh; þe goyng out of þe lure, chaufe or make hote apostolicon; which chaufed, be longaon touched with it, and alsone it schal entre agayn. ¶ If it be nede do it oftyme&yogh; when it goþ out; Afterward be it bathed in watre of plantane, of porre&yogh;, of peritory, or of peritorye sed solius parieturiæ alon. With þis medicyne was kyng henry of ynglond cured of þe goyng out of þe lure.
6: 18. Be a leche wele puruied þat he haue a couenable instrument for clistrye&yogh; to be ministred; þat is þat he haue a pipe of tree, namely of box, or of hesel þat availeþ mych, or of salowe, to þe length of 6 ynche&yogh; or 7 with on hole alon; ffor old men vsed pipes holed in þe side.  Bot witte þou for certayne þat, as I haue lered be experience, a pipe with one hole availeþ more, and &yogh;etteþ better in þe liquore. ¶ Afterward haue he a swyne&yogh; bledder, or a nete&yogh; bledder, no&yogh;t blowne to myche, which þou schalt preparate þus for to be kept.  Take þe forseid swyne&yogh; or nete&yogh; bladder when it is dry, and putte þerin a sponeful of comon salt, of water als mych, of hony als mych as of watre; latte þam be dissolued togidre in þe bledder by tuo daies naturale, And euery day tuyes or þries be þe bledder turned or shaken about, þat it may be wette of þe liquore on euery side.  Afterward be þat putte out þat is þer-in, and be þe bledder blowne, and be þe mouth bonden þat þe wynde go no&yogh;t out, and hyng it in ane vmbrose "schadowye" place vnto þat þer be had nede þer-of. Þis preparacion, forsoþ, kepeþ þe bledder fro corrupcion long tyme, And fro fretyng of worme&yogh;, and makeþ þe bladder strong and able to þe vse of the forseid werk. ¶ Be þe clistrye made þer after my maner, for it is li&yogh;t bot no&yogh;t lesse effectuale.  Many þings bene profitable to þe confeccion of clisteries, if þe lech mi&yogh;t haue al redy.  Bot oft-tyme þe leche may no&yogh;t fynde in euery place al þing&yogh; necessary to hym; þerfor it schal no&yogh;t vnworschip "ne schame" a lech for to spede profitabily with fewer þings and li&yogh;ter.  Old leche&yogh;, forsoþ, ordeyned costiuous "i. of gret cost" clystrye&yogh;, greuous and li&yogh;t, and þai putte in cassiam fistulam, mirobala&ntail;, rerepigre and oþer laxatiue&yogh;; which clisterie&yogh;, forsoþ, after þair receyuyng, made þe paciente&yogh; more constipate, i.[e.] encostyued, þan þai war before; And þerfor long tyme&yogh; and oft tyme&yogh; I haue proued and bene experte a li&yogh;ter maner of clystrying and more effectuous, as wele in childre and wymmen as in men, als wele in &yogh;ong men as in olde men; And in diuerse case&yogh; as in wounded men, constipate "costyue" men, and febrous men, and in colica & yliaca.  And I spedde effectuously with sich a clistre þat is þer made. ¶ Recipe malue&yogh; como&nmacr; and grene camamille, or drye if þou may haue it, and brisse þam a litel, and sethe þam in watre vnto þe watre become grene; þan tak whete branne als myche as sufficeþ, and putte it to þe forseid herbis and boile it a litel; afterward cole it, and to þe colyng adde to ane handful of salt and clene hony or oile; and be al wele resolued, mouyng it with a spature or with þi hande; þis confection, forsoþ, may be kept by a fourtni&yogh;t if it be nede. ¶ If malue&yogh;, forsoþ, or camamille may no&yogh;t be hadde, with water & branne and salt without any oþer þing þe forseid nede scha&llbar; be sped wele yno&yogh; for certayn. ffor whi; for certayne if a lech wanted a&llbar; oþer þing&yogh;, with water alon & salt boiled togidre and &yogh;ette in by a clistrye bringeþ out squiballe&yogh;. Bot witte þou þat þise bene necessary to þe confeccion of clistrie&yogh;, þat is to sey, Hony, oile, butter, salt, swyne&yogh; grese, sope white and blak, oile of camami&llbar;, oile of rwe, & oile of malue&yogh;, sanguis veneris, &c.  Of which forseid white sope may euer more be necessary to a leche, for it y-putte in þe forseid decoccione and þer schaken wele with þe hande mych strengtheþ þe clistrye; and þis may euer more be had redy.  Also hony when it may be hadde doþe grete help in euery clistery. ¶ Þise bene herbe&yogh; necessary to þe werk of clistry, scilicet Violette, malue&yogh;, camami&llbar;, mercurialis, watercresse, caule lefe&yogh;, peritorie, &c.;  Of which som wircheþ mollifying, as malue&yogh;; some dissoluyng, as camami&llbar;, peritorie, and oþer.  Bot wytte þou þat in clistrying þe leche owe for to augmente and lessen þe proporcion of salt after þat þe vertu of þe pacient may thole, i.[e.] suffre, for þe tendernes of longaon, and after þat he seþe þe pacient strong, softe or hard for to avoiden.  ffor grete quantite of salt makeþ sone þe clistery for to haste to þe goyng out, And mene quantite bryngeþ no&yogh;t out so sone.  Þerfor be þe lech waker in þis þat he be no&yogh;t negligent ne fole-hardy in his wirchyng.  ffor it is werk of a perfite maistrye.  ffor þe which I haue geten ane hundreþ tyme&yogh; grete honour with lucre in diuerse place&yogh;. ffor whi; at london when lumbarde&yogh; of-tyme&yogh; ministred clisterie&yogh; on þair maner to colic men and oþer men constipate, "encostiued" ne my&yogh;t no&yogh;t availe, Ego cum predicto modo clisteri&yogh;andi primo vice infra spatium unius stadii vel duorum patientem, deo mediante, deliveravi pro certo . Sloane 56, leaf 24. I, forsoþ, with þe forseid maner of clistriyng, at þe first tyme within þe space of a forlong or of tuo, I deliuered þe pacient for certayne, our lord beyng mene. ¶ When þou wilt forsoþ giffe a clistre, Tak of þe forseid decoccion half a quart at þe moste and putte it in þe bladder, and putte þe gretter ende of þe pipe into þe bladder, and bynde it faste; and anoynte þe forþer end of þe pipe with fresch swyne&yogh; grese, or with butter, or with popilion, or with comon oile, or with hony. And putte in þi fynger, anoynted first with some of þe forseid þings, into þe lure; And alsone putte in þe pipe of þe clistre into þe lure.  And þan ow þe leche for to presse þe bladder with þe liquore atuix his honde&yogh; and &yogh;ette in þe liquore.  And if he fynde as it war ane obstacle in &yogh;e wombe lettyng þe entryng of þe liquore, as it oftyme&yogh; falle&yogh;, þan draw agayne a litel þe pipe, and he schal fele þe liquore entre, and þan &yogh;ette in al þe liquore; which y-&yogh;ette in, make he þe pacient for to lye grouelyng aboue his bedde, and frote & robbe his wombe vpon þe nauyl with his owne hand or with anoþer manne&yogh;; And enforce he hymself als long as he may for to withhold þe clisterye, And when he may no longer hold it, go he to a sege made redy with a basyne standyng vnder-neþe and þer do his nede&yogh;.  And se þe lech þe egestions, wheþer it be blode or putride flemme &c, or wormes or squiballe&yogh; indurate, or wheþer colre go out or quiter &c.  And þus may þe leche be certified what is to do in euery cure. ¶ Ouer þat þis is namely to be written, þat when þe lech ministreþ clistery to any man, þat in &yogh;ettyng in þe liquore with þe clistery þe liquor alsone stirt out vpon þe hande&yogh; of þe leche, so þat þe pacient may no&yogh;t withhold it ne receyue it; and þat dure 2 daies or 3, for certayne sich a pacient is disposed to þe deþ without dout, þat is if þe liquor &yogh;etted in be no&yogh;t ouer scharp of þe salt.  Þerfor be þe leche circumspecte, "biholdyng aboute hym" for ful seldom haue I sene þis reule faile for certayn, bot neþerlesse it holdeþ no&yogh;t euer, þat is if þe sekene&yogh; go agayne to wele-fare. "or my&yogh;tynes" ¶ Also it is to witte þat when þe leche haþe wele clensed, bi þe clistery, þe wombe of fece&yogh; and oþer superfluite&yogh; seid afore, þan profiteþ it mych for to &yogh;ette in a clistery made of decoccione of malue&yogh;, if it may be hadde, and of branne and of butter & oile or swyne&yogh; grece.  If malue&yogh;, forsoþ, may no&yogh;t be had, þan be it made only of decoccion of branne and of þe toþer seid aboue, and be it &yogh;etted in by þe clistery. Be þis clistery forsoþe made without any salt, And þan owe þe pacient for to withhold it strongly by al a ni&yogh;t and longer. And þis scha&llbar; conforte þe bowelle&yogh; and schal mollifien þam, and schal kepe þam fro constreynyng vnto þai be filled with new fece&yogh;.  Elle&yogh;, forsoþ, of þe voidene&yogh; of þe bowelle&yogh; þe bowelle&yogh; schùld be constipate, as I haue oft tyme sene. ¶ It is to witte þat in curacione of þe colic no medicyne so sone helpeþ as clistery; ffor why; þis bryngeþ out hard squiballe&yogh; of what euery cause þai be withholden, And it avoideþ soueranly ventosene&yogh;, and wonderfully putteþ out viscose flemne & putrified.  Wherfor I haue oft-tyme&yogh; cured many paciente&yogh; with clistery without any oþer medicyne, And oft-tyme&yogh; within 3 houre&yogh;. And þerfor it spedeþ for to wirk first with a clistre in colic & yliaca passions; ffor þe lower bowelle&yogh; avoided of þair superfluite&yogh;, þe ouer bowelle&yogh; may more li&yogh;tly putte out fro þam þair superfluite&yogh; to þe lawer bowelle&yogh;. ¶ As auicen seiþ, al þe bowelle&yogh; of a mannes wombe ar continued with venis miseraicis, out-take longaon, for longaon is no&yogh;t continued to þam.  Wherfor þe lyuer may drawe to hym fro ouer bowe&llbar; somwhat, And by þis is it schewed þat if ane hole man bi any case be distitute of appetite of mete and drynk, þat he may no maner ete, þat by þe infusion into þe lure by a clistrye of any norischyng liquore, as of any potage or mylke of almande&yogh; or sich oþer, þe lyuer mygth draw þerof to hymself and so norisch þe body. ¶ Þerfor witte þou þat clisterie&yogh; no&yogh;t only availeþ to seke men and constipate, as of þe colic or of sich oþer, bot it availeþ to al men beyng in þe febre&yogh;, als wele acue&yogh; as crenic, i.[e.] long tyme lastyng, And to euery inflacion of þe wombe, and to ventosite of it, and torcions, i.[e.] gryndyng.  And som-tyme it availeþ mych in som fluxe&yogh; of þe wombe And for certayn it availeþ mich to hole men, constipate and no&yogh;t constipate, if þai be purged twyse at lest or 3 or four tyme&yogh; in a &yogh;ere with þe forseid clisterie&yogh;; þat is tuyse in wynter, and in vere as it war after lentyn one&yogh;, in somer one&yogh;, or ofter tyme if nede be. ¶ ffor why; þe benefite of it may no man noumbre; ffor as it helpeþ fair in necessite, so it preserueþ þam þat vseþ it fro harme & necessite: be it þerfor had in reuerence.
