[O]f atramente&yogh;, i.[e.] of vitriole&yogh;, bene many kynde&yogh;; And þat is better þat is more grene and þat is founden in þe yle of Crete "or cipre" ; and it is called comonly dragante, bot no&yogh;t dragagante, una species ffor dragagant is a white gumme and clere like vnto gumme arabic.  Also þer is a spice of vitriol þat is called vitriolum romanum, i.[e.] coporose; And it is of &yogh;alow colour in reward of in respectu viridioris . þe grenner vitriol. And þer is one of white colour bot no&yogh;t schynyng, and þat is seid to availe to þe cure&yogh; of ei&yogh;en.  Vitriol is hote "calidus" and drye "siccus" in þe 4 degre after platear, Secundum Platearium And þer ar 4 maners þerof: Indicum, þat is founden in ynde, and þat is white; Arabicum þat is founden in arabye, and þat is &yogh;elow; And ciprinum þat is founden in Cipre, and þat is grene; And romanum þat is coprose, þat is more grene is competent to medicyne.  It haþe strenght of dissoluyng, consumyng, fretyng. "corrodyng" It may be kepte by 10 &yogh;ere effectualy. Also vitriol combuste be itself or with salt combuste vputte vpon a venemyd wonde draweþ þe venym fro byneþ vnto aboue. ab inferius ad superius Also puluer of vitriol combuste streyneþ blode in euery place if it be putte by itself or with iuyse of any herbe streynyng blode, as of rede netle, or bursa pastoris, or moleyne, or walwort.  Also it is seid to availe agayns polipe in þe nose if it be putte into þe nose with a tente of coton and melle rosette medled with &yogh;olk of an ey; it freteþ superflue flesch, and putte into a fistule mortifieþ it.  And also it y-medled with diaquilon or apostolicon and y-put vpon fraudulent vlcere&yogh; ulcera fraudu[lenta] . in dry membre&yogh;, it cureþ þam meruelously in drawyng, and mortifieþ þam and freteþ þam.  Also if vitriol be combust it is lesse mordicatyue, but his dryne&yogh; is not lessened.  fforsoþ al spice&yogh; of vitriol bene scharp after lesse and more, and þai haue þair scharpne&yogh; in þair superficite; And when þai ar combuste þai bene exsiccatyue without grete mordicacion, and so in exsiccand þai gendre flesch, and most in drye membris and bodie&yogh;.  ffor why; Vitriol y-put to diuerse membris or diuerse membris Nam vitriolum diversis corporibus appositum vel membris . it is sene to haue diuerse effecte In dry bodie&yogh;, for as coloric and malencolious; And also putte in dry membre&yogh; when it fyndeþ strong membre&yogh; agaynstayndyng to his strenght, þan may he no&yogh;t bot dry superfluite&yogh; y-founden in vlcere&yogh; or in wonde&yogh;; which forsoþ y-dried, nature gendereþ flesch. In moist bodie&yogh;, forsoþe, as in fleumatike men and childre and wymmen, and in moiste membre&yogh; of þe bodie, þe membre&yogh; bene feble and may no&yogh;t withstande to þe strength of þe vitriol; and so þai suffre liquefaccion of it, and so putrefaccion is augmented in þe wonde.  And as it wirkeþ þus in diuerse bodie&yogh;, so wirkeþ it in diuerse complexions and diuerse membris.  And it doþe no&yogh;t þus for contrariouste of operacion þat it haþe in itself, bot for contrariouste of complexions to which it is y-putte; As fire doþ diuersely in dyuerse þings.  ffor whi; lede or oþer metalle as bras and siluer y-put to þe fire ar molten of þe fire; tyle, stone&yogh;, and erþen potte&yogh; y-putte to þe fire ar hardened; and þise be no&yogh;t done for þat þe fire haþe contrarious wirkyng in hymself, bot for contrariouste of nature of þe forseid þing&yogh;. Wherfor seiþ galiene, if þer be tuo þings euen in helþe, and þe tone be in a dry membre and þe toþer in a moiste, þat þat is in þe dry membre nedeþ more dry medycyne.  Emplastre&yogh;, forsoþ, þat ar putte to membre&yogh; owen to be of o kynd to þe membrys, after Ioℏn Damascene:  Tak of vitriol als mych as þou wilt, i.[e.] 2 vnce&yogh; or 3 or 4, and putte in ane erþen potte whos mouþe be wele stopped with clay distemperate with horse dong, þat is called lutum sapien, cujus orificium fortiter obturetur cum luto bene distemperat. cum flmo equino quod vero lutum sapienciæ dicitur . and sette it to dry; þe which y-dried, sette "birye" þe potte with þe vitriol among cole&yogh;, and make a softe fire by one houre; And after ane houre make it stronger, and blow strongly with belowe&yogh; 2 houre&yogh;, and after lette in pece vnto þat þe fire defaile by itself.  And þe potte y-colded, be it opned, and þou schalt fynde attrament, i.[e.] vitriol, of rede colour cleuyng to þe side&yogh; of þe potte; whiche remoued fro þe potte, be it poudred subtily vpon a stone, and putte it in a strong leþer bagge and kepe it to þine vse.  By sich combustion is his natural hete alterate and so it is colded, and so his mordicacion is dulled; wherfor it may restreyne blode in nose&yogh; and wounde&yogh; and lure and marice. Also it availeþ agayne&yogh; þe cancre and agayn&yogh; venemous aposteme&yogh; and fraudulente&yogh; contra apostemata venenosa et fraudulenta ; And to teþe or gome&yogh; freten or gnawen medled with symple hony, or better with melle rosate; Or best if þat licium, i.[e.] iuyse of caprifoile with clarefied hony be soþen to þe þikne&yogh; of hony, and be medled with puluer of vitriol and putte vnto þe gome&yogh;; ffor whi; Iuyse of caprifoile þat is called licium availeþ bi itself to al þe vice&yogh; of þe mouþe.  Also vitriol y-medled with hony and licium putte þer-in helpeþ to vlcere&yogh; of ere&yogh;, and to þe quitour of þam and fretyng.  Also vitriol combuste when it is medled with puluer of hermodactile&yogh; and putte vnder-neþ þe tung it helpeþ to þe ranule. "frog" Ane oyntment þat availeþ to cancrose vlcere&yogh;, and to wonde&yogh;, and to aposteme&yogh;, of which floweþ out blode, and to yuel carbuncle&yogh; þat ar called pestilenciale&yogh;, and to aposteme&yogh; þat ar made of yuel mater, is made þus: Recipe of old swyne grese adipis porci vetustissimi. ounce iii, vitriol ounce iiii.  Be þe grese molten ouer þe fire & be it coled, and breke long tyme þe vitriol with oile in a brazen morter, and afterward medled with þe grese ouer þe fire, and make ane oyntement mych fruyteful.  If þou wilt make it in maner of one emplastre, putte þer-to wax and blak pich, for pich haþe strenght or vertu of drawyng fro partie&yogh; bineþ to aboue, and þe same doþe vitriol.

1.1: 20. Alum &yogh;ucaryne is called comonly alumglasse.  It is hote "calidus" and dry "siccus" in þe 4 degre.  It is a veyne of þe erþe y-knowen yno&yogh;, satis cognita et commune bot how mych it is more clere & schynyng so mych is it better.  It haþe strenght of consumyng and of gretly desickyng. "drying" It availeþ with hote vinegre agayn&yogh; inflacions of þe gome&yogh;; And it availeþ in medicyne&yogh; agayn&yogh; þe scabbe. Also poudre of it combuste profiteþ mich bi itself, or y-medled with hony, in mundifying of li&yogh;t cure&yogh;. It mundifieth, forsoþ, with a stiptikne&yogh;, cum quadam stipicitate and in þat þat in hoc quod. it is stiptik it is confortatyue of membre&yogh;, for al stiptik þing&yogh; bene repressiue of humours.  Þer is, forsoþe, anoþer kynde of alum þat is called alumen scissum, comonly alum plume, and it haþe þrede&yogh; and it may be diuided and ryuen in sondre.  And it is ri&yogh;t gode, and it haþe þe same vertue&yogh; as alum glasse.  Alum glasse is brynt þus: Tak a tile stone or a scarþe of a potte, Accipe unam tegulam vel testam unius olle . and putte it in þe midde&yogh; of brynnyng cole&yogh; so þat þe cole&yogh; touch it no&yogh;t, and in þat scarþe putte þe hole pece of alum, and alsone it will melt as it war yse, and boile, and afterward it wexeþ hard; and in boilyng it will blow and wex hi&yogh;e in drying and wexing white.  And lat it be stille so in þe fire vnto þe blowyng and boilyng vtterly cese, and to it be bro&yogh;t into ful white colour; þe which y-sene, sette it fro þe fire and poudre it ful smal vpon a stone, and in a leþer bag kepe it to þine vse.  Water of alum is made þus: Tak a quantite of it als mich as þou wilt, and breke it at þe best, et teratur optime . to which be added to 8 partie&yogh; of gode vinegre and strong, and so boile þam in a panne at þe fire vnto þat þe half parte of al-togidre be consumed.  Afterward remoue it fro þe fire and cole it; And þis is called watre of alum, which availeþ agayn&yogh; ychyng of scabbe of salt flemne.  And þis watre mundifieþ in coldand, bot watre of sulphur mundifieþ in hetyng or chaufand. valet contra pruritum scabei ex salso flemate et ista aqua mundificat infrigidando, sed aqua sulphuris mundificat calefaciendo

2.1: 21. Viride es i.[e.] vertgre&yogh;, is hote "calidus" and drye. "siccus" It is ful penetratyue and dissolutyue, and it prikkeþ and brynneþ and melteþ, and repressiþ putrefaccion.  Wharfor, after galiene, [cap.] 4 de ingenio, of wex and oile and vertgrese may be made anoyntement temperate.  ffor whi; vertegrese is ful mich penetratife, dissolutiue, pungityue, vrityue, uritinum . and liquefactyue.  And al þise ar repressed and dulled of wex and oile adde to it; for siþe wax and oile moisteþ ri&yogh;t mich and gendreþ putrefaccion, þai dulle þe scharpne&yogh; of vertgrese, And vertgrese represseþ þeir putrefaccion and humeccacion; wherfor of þise bene made a temperate oyntement.

3.0: 22. Of þe properte&yogh; of arsenic & auripigment.
3.1: 22. [A]rsenic & auripigment bene boþe one, bot arsenic is no&yogh;t so fair as auripigment; neþerlesse boþe haue a &yogh;alow colour, but auripigment is gretter and more schynyng, and more disesy for to grynde for his þredine&yogh;; for in substance he is like vnto plaistre of paris. Bot arsenic is as it war puluer in reward of auripigment, and it is more li&yogh;tly broken; And when it is broken it haþe as it war vermilion within it, of rede colour and of a&yogh;our colour; which vnkunnyng men saiþ to be realgre, & þat is false.  ffor whi; realgre is ane artificial confection made of alkenemistre&yogh; secundum modum alkimistarum id est alkenemyers . bi sublimacion, as arsenic sublimed, And for certayn þai ar no&yogh;t different in operacion in any þing, out-take þat realgre is of rede colour, and arsenic sublimed is of white colour; bot neþerle&yogh; arsenic entreþ in confeccion of realgre, And forþi realgre is called of som men rede auripigment: of þe name&yogh; is no stryuyng so þat we vnderstond þe þing&yogh;. Auripigment is hote and dry in þe 4 degre, of whiche bene tuo spice&yogh; as is seid aboue, &yogh;elow and rede.  &YOGH;elow is more competent to vse of leche&yogh;. It is forsoþ dissolutyue, attractyue, and mundificatyue, And it haþe in it a vertue putrefactyue by which he putrefieþ straunge humours comyng to a wounde, or ane vlcere, þat þai may no&yogh;t be assimilate, i.[e.] liken to membre&yogh;, and engendre superflue flesch or dede flesch.  Also it availeþ in medicyne&yogh; agayn&yogh; þe scabbe, þe tetre and white morfee y-medled with blak sope.  And for þat we made mencion of arsenic sublimed, þerfor it is to witte þat no leche bot if he be more experte in cirurgie presume for to wirk with realgre or arsenic sublimed.  ffor of þam ar bredde many disese&yogh; for þair distemperate violence.  ffor why; þai boþe wirk with one maner and violence, and þat more violently þan cautery of fire.  And if any man ow for to vse þam, þam owe to be putte to in þe lest quantite, for þe vertu of þam aboute fire is þe vttermoste of strenght, Quoniam virtus eorum circa ignem in ultimo fortitudinis et quod patet and þat is schewed, for þe watre of þam freteþ euery meta&llbar;, out-tak gold.  Witte þou þat auripigment is called comonly ortment, orpigment whos puluer vseþ falconere&yogh; agayn&yogh; pedicle&yogh; "lise" of þaire falcone&yogh;.  Also witte þou þat auripigment is desiccatyue, consumptiue, euaporatyue, eradicatyue, putrefactiue, ruptyue and cauteriatyue. Also witte þou þat of arsenic sublimed or of realgre, þat one&yogh; in a tyme in þe bigynnyng of my practi&yogh;ing, when I knew no&yogh;t þe violence of þam, I putte of þe puluer of þe tuo forsayd in þe legge&yogh; of tuo men; þe which, forsoþe, y-putte in, almost þei wer wode for ake bi tuo daie&yogh; naturel and more; And þair legge&yogh; war bolned out of mesure.  Þe þrid daie, forsoþe, þe place wher þe puluer was putte appered of ri&yogh;t blak colour, and þe paciente&yogh; war so feble þat þai war almost dede.  Þan I anoynted þair legge&yogh; with oile of rose or popilion, And I fomented þe leggis in hote water for to euapour yuel humours contened in þe membre&yogh;; And aboue þe place I putte rawe larde kytted þinne, apposui lardum crudum tenue incisum with oile of rose.  Aboue þe larde putte I ane emplastre of þe &yogh;olke&yogh; of raw egge&yogh;, And stuppe&yogh; of lyne aboue for to hold þe larde.  And aboute þe 9 daie þe place combuste beganne to dissolue in þe circumference and for to putte out quiter.  And þe place no&yogh;t reparate bot fro þe þrid day to þe þrid daye de 3o in 3m. I continued euer-more þis cure in þe forseid maner, vnto þat al þe mortified flesch within was fully putte out þe which, forsoþ, putte out, þe bone of þe legge "schine" appered bare with a wounde ri&yogh;t horrible; þe which y-sene, I filled þe wonde of stupe&yogh; y-kitte smalle, and putte þam aboue þe naked bone; and I putte in of þe &yogh;olk of a raw egg wele temperate with sanguine veneris, and I filled al þe wounde þer-with; and so euery day one&yogh; reparalyng it vnto þe quiter biganne to cese, and þe side&yogh; of þe wounde byganne for to sonde or conglutinate.  And witte þou þat when þe side&yogh; of þe wounde come to þe place of þe bone cauteri&yogh;ide of þe arsenic, which was blakke, þai mi&yogh;t no more grewe, for þe mortified bone mi&yogh;t no&yogh;t receyue nutriment, þat þer mi&yogh;t no flesch grew vpon it, ne be regendred.  Þe which &yogh;itte sene, I, sewyng þe ignorance of þe comon puple, Quo adhuc viso, ignorantiam vulgi prosecutus . euery day I schoue Abrasi . þe bare bone with instrument preparate þer-to, entendyng for to gendre flesch vpon þe bare bone.  And I putte to regeneratyue&yogh; of flesch, þat is to sey licium with mel rosate, and puluer of aloes, & mastike, and mirre, sarcoco&llbar;, san. draconis, and þai profited noþing.  Neþerle&yogh; þe schauying euery day continued in þe maner of ydiote&yogh;, as I seid afore; a daye, as I schoue þe forseid bone, þe bare bone vnder þe instrument moued vp and downe; þat, forsoþ, perceyued, I meruailed ouer mesure, neþerle&yogh; I perceyued of þat þat þe schauyng of þe bone profited noþing: fro þan forþe I lefte þat werk, and I putte noþing elle&yogh; in þe wounde bot licium with melle rosate and &yogh;olk of a raw aye ymedled togidre, with carped stupe&yogh; of lyne, and so fro day to day continuyng vnto þe forseid bone,  flesch growyng vnder-neþe appered hi&yogh;er þan þe extremite&yogh; of þe wounde, and was made more moueable and more; þe which ysene, I putte þe poynt of a knyfe vnder þe side of þe bone and I raised it a litel, and al þe bare bone stirt out, and rede flesch had filled al þe space where þe bone laye, and blode went out.  Þat bone, forsoþe, had in length 4 ynche&yogh;, and 2 in brede; in þikne&yogh;, forsoþe, it was drawne out almost vnto þe merewgh of þe bone; And þis was in þe schyne bone.  After þe seperacion, forsoþe, of þe bone, I cured finaly þe wounde with licium and mel rosate and raw &yogh;olk of an ey and puluer sine pari.  And þe pacient recouered wonderfully his goyng; he was, forsoþe, a &yogh;ong man.  And as it fe&llbar; on þe tone man, one þe same maner felle it of þe toþer.  And witte þou þat I putte no&yogh;t of puluer of arsenic in þe legge&yogh; of þe forseid men ouer þe quantite of a corne of senvey, "a mosterd sede" and neþerlesse þe wonde&yogh; þat come of þe arsenic passed fully þe lengthe and þe brede of a manne&yogh; hande.  Þerfor vnexperte men be wele war fro þe vse of realgre and arsenic sublimed, and namely in þe face and þe legge&yogh;, and synowy place&yogh; and bony, and in a manne&yogh; &yogh;erde, and in þe lure; for bot if þai haue grete resistence þai wirke ful cruely.

4.0: 23. Of makyng of þem & of þe werchynge.
4.1: 23. [L]icium is þe iuyse of caprifoile, þat is called wodebynde, and it groweþ in wode&yogh; and wyndeþ strongly aboute tree&yogh;; and it haþ long floure&yogh;, and it bereþ swete rede berie&yogh;.  Licium cureþ þe canker in þe marice and in oþer inward membre&yogh;, for it haþe vertu mundificatyue, consolidatyue, and confortatyue, and regeneratyue of flesch in a bare bone and in schynne bone&yogh;; and it haþe a vertu mundificatyue of putrefiyng of þe bone.  And generaly it availeþ in al fretyng sekene&yogh;, as in cancre, lupe, fistule, and noli-me-tangere.  And agayne þe cancre in þe mouþe licium is a principal medicyne, boiled with hony vnto þe þikne&yogh; of þe hony.  And it may be þus made: þe iuyse schal be pressed out and sette to þe son for to dry vnto þat it may be pulueri&yogh;ed.  And þis pulueri&yogh;ed availeþ to derke ei&yogh;en, putte in þe ei&yogh;, and forþi is called oculus lucidus. Bot it may be made profitably oþer wyse, availyng to ful cause of cirurgie, & þat þus: þe iuyse of caprifoile pressed out bi itself, be it boiled with alse mich of clarified hony vnto þe wastyng of þe iuyse, and be it kepte vnto vse. And þis availeþ to þe cancre in þe mouþe, and in þe lure, and in þe marice, and al cancrose vlcere&yogh; and fraudulent&yogh; of legge&yogh;.  If þe iuyse, forsoþ, may no&yogh;t li&yogh;tly be pressed out for þe þikne&yogh;, als it falleþ, oft tyme, þan be þe lefe&yogh; watred with gode white wyne or rede, and þan may þe iuyse li&yogh;tly be pressed out.  ffor whi; witte þou þat caprifoile owe no&yogh;t to be waschen with watre afore þe brissyng, and moste when þer owe to be made licium to cure&yogh; of þe ei&yogh;en, Bot if it nede alwaie&yogh; to be wette, be it no maner done with watre bot with wyne, as it is seid.  Also lefe&yogh; of caprifoile brissed by þam-self and with al his substance without medlyng of any oþer þing, putte vpon vlcere&yogh; of legge&yogh; desperate & stynkyng, and puttyng out foule blode, and growyng hi&yogh;e to maner of a cancre, and vnobedient to any medicyne, cureþ þam happily and meruelously.  And þis proued I in þe legge of a grete man hauyng a pustle, In curyng of which al medicyne&yogh; defailed; and with þis was he cured.  ffor whi; þe first tyme þat it was putte to it dried þe fistule, and did away þe stynkyng and al þe yuel accident&yogh;, and within a moneþ he was plenarely cured.

5.0: 24. Of makyng of pulv. sine pari & of þe wirchyng.
5.1: 24. [P]uluis sine pari, or french Poudre san&yogh; pere, is made þus: Recipe auripigment. parte 1, þat [is] ounce ii; vertgrese ana, or after som men partes ij; Of vitriol combuste, or no&yogh;t combuste, als mich as of boþe þe forseid; Alum &yogh;ucarine combust, or no&yogh;t combuste, als mych as of al þe forseid.  Ich on of þise bi þamself be ful subtily grouden on a stone, þe which wele y-growden, be þei eft-sone grouden al to-gidre vnto þai be ri&yogh;t wele medled; and putte þam in leþer bag, and kepe to vse: þis may be kepte bi a &yogh;ere and longer, and þat in gret effecte.  Þis poudre is seid "without pere" ffor it haþe no pere in wirchyng; ffor why; it mortifieþ and bryngeþ out dede flesch or superflue or putred in al wonde&yogh; and vlcere&yogh;.  And witte þou þat þis puluis bigileþ neuer þe paciente ne þe cirurgene, for it doþ not wickedly.  ffor whi; if þe cirurgene bene vnkunnyng and putte þis puluis in a wonde or in ane vlcere no&yogh;t hauyng dede flesch, it doþ none harme to þe wonde or þe vlcere; bot without any oþer help it schal at þe best be conglutinatiue, dissiccatyue, and sanatyue of þe wonde; bot neþerlesse no&yogh;t without mordicacion.  ffor, for certayne, if þis puluis war no&yogh;t mordicatyue it schuld in prise passe al medicyne&yogh;.  Þe vse of þis puluis is sich; when þis puluis is putte in a wounde or in ane vlcere, be þer putte to it, without any-þing atuix, cotone or stupe&yogh; of lyne cutte smalle with schere&yogh;; And þan aboue al þat be put aboue emplastre Nerbone or anoþer, and be it bounden, and so latte it be wiþout remouyng by two nyghte&yogh;. After þis tyme, forsoþ, when þou remoue&yogh; þe emplastre and þe coton or þe stupe&yogh; putte aboue þe puluis, If þe puluis putte in go willfully out with þe dede flesch þi nede&yogh; is wele sped.  Þan owe þou for to putte in þe hole of þe vlcere or of þe wonde a drop or tuo of sanguis veneris, with stuppe&yogh; of lyne or coton, vnto þat þe hole be eftsone&yogh; replete with flesch.  And if, forsoþ, in þe first remouyng þe puluis putte in come no&yogh;t wilfully out with þe mortified flesch, þan ow þe lech for to putte o droppe or tuo of sanguis veneris vpon þe puluis in þe wounde or þe vlcere, and aboue coton or stuppe&yogh; of lyne, as it is seid. And aboue al-togidre þe emplastre Nerbone; and so lat it abyde by a naturale day or more after þe estimacion of þe discrete leche.  And when þe dede flesch goþ out of þe vlcere or of þe wounde, be it reparailed as it was seid afore. And to a leche be þis a reule, þat puluis corrosyue be neuer remoued in a wonde or ane vlcere byfor þat it wille wilfully go out.  Also þer is anoþer reule in which I haue sene erre in my tyme almost al men no&yogh;t practi&yogh;ours bot fole&yogh;; þat is to say of þe ofte remouyng of wounde&yogh; or vlcere&yogh;.  Siche operacion, for-soþe, spedeþ no&yogh;t, bot letteþ couenable effecte of curyng.  And þat by þis reson, for natural hete in þe body, which is principal actour of curyng, expireþ "breþeþ" out of ofte remeuyng of a wounde or of ane vlcere, and so is letted digestion of humours comyng to þe wounde or to þe vlcere, Wherfor þer may no&yogh;t be nade generacion of quitour and, by sewyng, ne purgyng of þe wounde.  Wherfor superflue humours rennyng to þe wounde ar gedred togidre and ar holden stil more and more; wherfor þe bolnyng in þe wounde is augmented and, by sewyng, þe ake; for þe tone is occasion of þe toþer. Wherfor þe wounde or þe vlcere waxeþ hard and foule, and for þe quitour þat it owed of ri&yogh;t to putte out, it sendeþ out watry humour & venemous, and so ofte-tyme&yogh; of li&yogh;t hurtyng ar made incurable yuele&yogh;.  Also þer is anoþer errour in ofte remeuyng of wounde&yogh; or of vlcere&yogh;; ffor as seiþ philosophre&yogh;, aier chaungeþ þe body and by consequens þe wounde, and þat may be proued by experience. Þe breþ of a menstruous woman noyeþ vnto wounde&yogh; if sche ne&yogh;en nere; Or of þe lech if he haue liggen with his wife or with anoþer woman menstruate, or if he haue eten garleke or onyons.  Bot be þis maner of wirchyng boldly holden, þat a lech be content only of ane reparacione in þe day, þat is if he haue þe medicyne&yogh; contened in þis boke.  ffor when he seþe a wounde or ane vlcere wele cast out quitour, and þe bolnyng for to vanysh away, and þe akyng for to be cesed, and þe membre for to come agayne to þe first habite and colour, helþe is at þe dore if þe pacient be we[le] gouerned, i.[e.] if he slepe wele in ni&yogh;tes.  In slepe, forsoþ, nature wirkeþ better aboute digestion of euery mater beyng in þe body or in þe membris.  Bot for þat slepe is oftyme letted of akyng, þerfor bifore al þing&yogh; be it laboured þat þe akyng be cessed. ffor akyng&yogh; afor al oþer þings no&yogh;t only presseþ downe vertue&yogh; of þe body but also of þe medicyne&yogh;.  And þat þing soueranly mitigateþ oile of rose in hote cause, or oile of camamille in cold cause, for it is hote and resolutyue, of which it schal be seid afterward. Also ane emplastre of hony and branne and a litil vinegre fried togidre mitigateþ "eseþ" euery akyng for certayne. And witte þou þat þo þing&yogh; þat ar putte aboue makeþ to þe closyng-in of naturale hete and excludyng of þe aier.  Be þise þing&yogh; seid afore of remeuyng of wounde&yogh; and vlcere&yogh; comended wele to mynde; And be it done boldly as it is seid, ffor oftyme&yogh; in many case&yogh; I was no&yogh;t wount for to remoue bot fro þe þrid day into þe þrid day, and þat namely in hurtyng of þe schynne&yogh;; and I sped wele, And I cured many hard þing&yogh; and forsaken of oþer men with þis puluis sine pari and oþer emplastre&yogh; y-named.  And I saw neuer in al my tyme þis forseid puluis defaile, outtake in þe legge of a gret man in which it mi&yogh;t no&yogh;t haue no strength of wirchyng as it was wont for to haue in oþer; wherfor I was hugely astoned, bot neþerle&yogh; I heled hym wele with grene licium putte þer-to, our lorde beyng mene, as it is seid aboue.

6.0: 25. Of makyng of sanguis veneris & of þe wirchyng.
6.1: 25. [A]nd for þat many men couaiteþ for to here name&yogh; of oile&yogh; and of emplastre&yogh; and of oyntement&yogh;, þerfor I haue putte þair name&yogh; to þam.  One for þe rednes and swetne&yogh; is called sanguis veneris.  Of french, forsoþ, for ladie&yogh; is called sank damours or sank de pucel&lbar;, ffor why;  venus was called godde&yogh; of luffe. Sanguis veneris ow þus to be made: Recipe puluis of alcannet ounce 1. and putte it in a quart of comon oile, and þe oile schal become rede to likne&yogh; of blode, wheþer it be boiled at þe fire or no&yogh;t, for it may be made on boþe maners; and be it kept to vse in ane erþen potte or a pewdre potte.  Þis maner of confeccion of sanguis veneris is ri&yogh;t gode for þe alkenet þat is cold and drye in þe first or second gre.  ffor þis alkenet consumeþ humidite&yogh; of wounde&yogh; and of vlcere&yogh;, for it is subtiliatyue and resolutyue without mordicacion, and carminatyue & appertyue, and exsiccatyue with stiptikne&yogh;.  Wherfor it is gode in hote aposteme&yogh; with litel mater in þe bygynnyng, for it is cold and drye and þerfor it is repercussyue and exsiccatyue of hote aposteme&yogh;.  Also it helpeþ to synues and iuncture&yogh;, and vlcere&yogh; of þe mouþe in drying.  And it medled with vinegre & ynoynted helpeþ to þe akyng of þe heued.  Sanguis veneris heleþ wele, and purgeþ, and defendeþ fro drede depe wounde&yogh; made wyth knyfe or arow, and holow vlcere&yogh;, if it be putte in with stuppe&yogh; of lyne, And emplastre Nerbone putte aboue, And it doþe al þing&yogh; þat perteneþ to cure of a wounde or of aposteme, and þat in a fair maner.
6.2: Bot witte þou þat Sanguis veneris may be made on anoþer maner, and þat to noble men, if þe lech may haue in tyme of his confection al þings necessarye vnto his confection, þat is to sey þe blode of a maiden virgyne or of a maiden damisel about 19 or 20 &yogh;ere, which was neuer impregned, "with child" þof sche be corrupte; for now in þis tyme&yogh; virgine&yogh; comeþ ful seldome to 20 &yogh;ere.  Which blode ow to be drawen out in þe ful of þe mone, þe mone beyng in virgine and þe sonne beyng in piscib&yogh;.  Also it bihoueþ þe lech haue to þis confection aloes, & mirre, & sanguis draconis, and puluis of alkenet.  And þus is it made: Recipe blode of a maid, as it is seid afore, to þe which alsone after þe drawyng out, or it be cold, medle puluis of aloes cicotrine, mirre, sanguis draconis ana ounce 1 or 2 or 3, after þe quantite of þe blode; of subtile puluis of alkenet als mich as of al þe toþer.  And al þise, forsoþe, be wele medled with þe blode in maner of a paste, and afterward dry it at þe son: when it is drie kepe it to þine vse. When þou wilt, forsoþe, vse þerof, tak a party of it or al, and poudre it wele, and seþe it in grene oile of olyue&yogh; als mich as sufficeþ; þat is to ane vnce of þe forseid confection þou ow to putte 2 lb. of oile, þat is a quart of a galon, or more if it be nede, and boile þam togidre vnto þat þe oile appere rede; which beyng rede, putt it of þe fire, (sette it of þe fire) and kepe it to þine vse.  And when it is boiled cole it no&yogh;t bot lat it abide with þe oile, for it will satle in þe grounde, and so it will strengþe þe medicyne.

7.0: 26. Of makyng of salus populi & of þe werchyng.
7.1: 26. [A]n oyntment þat is called Salus populi is made þus: Recipe celidon M. ij, edere terrestris "hayhoue, folefote, horshoue" M. i, and brysse þam togidre; and afterward take herte&yogh; talow or schepe&yogh; talow or boþe, als mych as sufficeþ to þe quantite of þe herbe&yogh;; And of oile of olyue als myche als half of þe talow; and boile al with þe forseid herbe&yogh; vnto þat þe herbe&yogh; go to þe grounde of þe vessel and be made blak; afterward cole þam and lat þam cold, and kepe it to vse.  Þis oyntment is hard, and þerfore when it is nede to vse it take of it and putte in ane holow oistre schelle and melt it aboue cole&yogh;, or aboue a brynnyng candel; And wher þat nede is anoyte þerwith.  And witte þou þat it ow no&yogh;t to be putte in wounde&yogh; or vlcere&yogh; bot only about þam withoutforþe, þat is if þe skynne about þe wounde be flaien or skalded of hete, or if it haue many pusche&yogh; "blayne&yogh;" & smale, white or rede or blak; þan be þe skyn first wele fomented with a sponge & hote watre, And after þat it is dried be it anoynted with þis anoyntment hote aboue þe place flaien or pusched, And alsone without any þing atuix: if it be nede in grete case&yogh; þou may anoynte it aboue with vnguento arabico or with comon vnguento albo for to kele it more strongly and dry.
7.2: Salus populi, forsoþ, dryeþ wele and sicatri&yogh;eþ, and it availeþ at þe best to lippe&yogh; y-brent of þe sone or chynned of þe wynde, and to legge&yogh; and fete and hande&yogh;; and it availeþ agayn&yogh; brynnyng of fire, and it quencheþ þe wild fire after þe fallyng of þe pusche&yogh;.  Þis oyntment wold I neuer wante for many benefete&yogh; of it, And witte þou þat it is best remedi to þam þat haþe þe emoroides or þe fistule or oþer sleiyng.

8.0: 27. Of makyng of nerbone & of þe werchyng.
8.1: 27. [A]ne emplastre þat is called Nerbone is made þus: Recipe diaquilon, and with comon oile or with oleo siriaco resolue it vp[on] þe cole&yogh;, and boile it alwaie&yogh; with a spatulre vnto it bigynne to wex blak.  And if þou wil haue it ri&yogh;t blak boile it langer, and if þou wilt haue broune boile it lesse.  ffor whi; by long boilyng it may be made most blak without medlyng of any oþer þing. And after þat þou wilt haue it hard or softe be added þerto, or minusched, oile with which it is resolued.  When it haþ boiled ynou&yogh; sette it fro þe fire and late it stande stille without mouyng by þe space of a 'pater noster' & 'aue maria,' þat þe litarge of þe lede þat is in it may descende to þe grounde; and alsone be it &yogh;ette out softly into anoþer panne þat þe litarge be no&yogh;t &yogh;ette out withal&lbar;, and þan moue it with a spature strongly vnto þat it be colded.  When, forsoþ, it is cold þat it may be malaxed, enforme þerof trocistes vpon a table in quantite as it pleseþ þe, and kepe it to þine vse.  Þis emplastre is called Noirbone, for þof-al it be blak neþerlesse it is gode, for it heleþ wele wonde&yogh; and vlcere&yogh;, and it is wele cleuyng to, and it matureþ wele aposteme&yogh; and bresteþ þam in any place of þe body.

0.1: 28. [O]leum Siriacum is þus made: Recipe comon malue&yogh; of gardyne&yogh;, fatte & fresch, and somewhat brisse hem in a morter, And after boile hem long in comon oile bot no&yogh;t vnto þe consumyng of þe herbe, þat þe fatnes of þe malue&yogh; be no&yogh;t consumed.  And if þou wilt make it þikke to maner of ane emplastre, þan ow þou for to putte with þe oile as war þrid parte of schepe&yogh; talow, and boile hem togidre as it is seid, and kepe it to vse.

1.0: 29. Of makyng of Unguentum arabicum.  Of makyng of tapsimel.  Of makyng of diaflosmus.
1.1: 29. Vnguentum arabicum, Tapsimel (in þe last end of emoroide&yogh;), Diaflosmos: seke hem in þe tretyse of þe fistule&yogh;.

2.1: 30. Puluis grecus is þus made: Recipe auripigment. citrin. piper. nigri, calcis viue, alphice, i.[e.] barlymele ana, hony clarified partes iij, vinegre þe ferþe parte; be þai medled with þe forseid poudre&yogh; in maner of paste, and be þer made a kake þerof, and be it baken on a hote tyle stone ouer þe fire so þat it be no&yogh;t brent bot þat it may be wele poudred vpon a stone.  And when it bigynneþ to wex blak on þe tile-stone be it oftyme turned þat it be no&yogh;t brent bot þat [it] be perfitely dried.  With þis puluis haue I cured sich fike&yogh; puttyng out blode, & growyng in þe palme of a manne&yogh; hand.  And if þou haue no&yogh;t puluis grecus þou may do þe same in þe forseid þings with puluis sine pari.  And wytte þou þat I haue oft tyme sene puluis grecus for to availe in þe cancre of a manne&yogh; &yogh;erde, and in fike&yogh; bredyng þer-aboute.

3.0: 31. Of makyng of oyle of roses.
3.1: 31. [O]ile of rose&yogh; is þus made: Recipe roses þat bene ful spred, and gredre hem erly while&yogh; þe dew lasteþ, and clyppe hem with a paire [of] schere&yogh; in smale pecys and do hem into a glasen vessel, and do þerto oile of olyue of þe grenest þat þou may fynde, ana, & medle hem wele togidre in þi vessel and stoppe it wele; And hete it agayn&yogh; þe son 20 daie&yogh; and þan draw it þur&yogh; a kanua&yogh; and cast away þe grounde&yogh; of þe rose&yogh;, And putte þat liquour þat comeþ out into a vessel a&yogh;eyn and stoppe þe vessel þat þer come none aier out.  And ich day in þe mornyng when þou schalt hyng out þi potte tak a spature of tre and opne þi potte and stirre it wele, and stoppe it agayne duryng al þe 20 daies.
3.2: Anoþer maner [of] makyng, and more colde.  Recipe rose&yogh; & oile ana, and schred þi roses and putte hem into a vessel of glasse with þine oile, and stoppe it wele.  And hang it into a vessel with watre vp to þe nek duryng tuo moneþe&yogh;, and euer ich day stirre it one&yogh; and stoppe it  a&yogh;eyn.  And after þat streyne it and do away þi grounde&yogh; of þe rose&yogh;.  And þis is more cold þan þe toþer.  Also it is made þus after my maner and myne vse.  If þou haue no&yogh;t plente of rose&yogh; take of white roses with þe tendrons of þe braunche&yogh; als mych as þou wilt, and brisse þam in a morter; þe which y-brissed, putte þam in als mych comon oile as þe likeþ, and so latte þam rest 9 daies; afterward boile þam vpon softe fire vnto þe oile be made grene.  Þan if þou may haue fresch rose&yogh; putte þam in ane erþen potte or leden, als many as þe likest; and be þe forseid oile coled hote &yogh;ette aboue and moued togidre with a spature, And alsone stoppe þe mouþe, þat þe vapour go no&yogh;t out. And biry þe vessel with þe oile in moist erþe, and euery oþer day be þer &yogh;etted cold watre about þe potte.  And be it þus done 40 daies or more, & þis maner confection schal be most noble oile roset.  And þus ow it to stonde al þe hole &yogh;ere.

4.0: 32. Of makyng of oyle of violette&yogh;
4.1: 32. Oile of violette&yogh; may be made in þe same maner. Bot witte þou þat oile of violettes is laxatiue and oile of rose constrictiue. ffor why; if oile of violett&yogh; with euen porcion of iuyse of Mercurial "smerwort" be &yogh;etted in by a clistery in continuel acue&yogh; or interpolate, it remolleþ softely þe bowele&yogh; and putteþ out þe superfluite&yogh;.  Oile of violet haþe aspecte to membre&yogh; þat bene dried by any infirmitè.  It abateþ bolnyng&yogh; wher þat euer þai be; And it softneþ þe asperitè "scharpne&yogh;" of þe brest and of þe long, and it ceseþ pleuresy and hote aposteme&yogh;.  And witte þou þat þer is tuo manere&yogh; of oile roset, complete and rude.  Complete is made of ripe oile and of ful rose&yogh; ripe.  Rude is made of vnripe oile and of rose&yogh; þat haþe [not?] fully opned þair budde&yogh;.  Oile roset complete is resolutiue, confortatyue, and conueniently cedatyue "cesyng" of akyng.  Rude forsoþe is extinctyue of inflammacions, confortatyue, aggregatyue, inspissatyue, prohibityue of curse&yogh; of humours.  Oile of roses is special remedy agayns brennyng and hote aposteme&yogh;, wher þat euer þai be in þe body.  ffor whi; in ane or tuo puttyngs to it mitigateþ þe akyng, it dulleþ þe furiositè and þe scharpne&yogh; of þe mater; It makeþ þe place for to vnbolne, "swage" and it remeueþ þe rede colour.  ffor-soþe it swageþ and softeneþ þe brennyng & þe prikkyng, þe smertyng and þe akyng, And it comforteþ þe membres boþ in hote causes and in cold; ffor after auctours, Oile roset coldeþ ane hote membre and heteþ a cold membre.  And it doþ many oþer profite&yogh; in þe body, And þerfor a gode lech puruey hym þat he want neuer oile rosette, syþe þer procedeþ so many helpyng&yogh; of it to manne&yogh; body.  ffor why; after galien, to euery akyng hote oile rosette is mitigatyue, as it is seid afore.

5.0: 33. Of makyng of oyle of camamulle.
5.1: 33. [O]ile of camamille is þus made: Recipe camamille grene and fresch, and brisse it somwhat in a morter.  After boile it with a softe fire in comon oile als mych as sufficeþ.  And putte a litel watre in þe oile þat þe herbe in seþing be no&yogh;t brent; and boile it vnto þe herbe&yogh; go doune to þe grounde and bigynne to be blak.  Which y-done, take flours of camamille, if þou may haue þam, and putte þam in ane erþen potte; And &yogh;ette þe forseid oile coled, als hote as it may, aboue þe floure&yogh;, and alsone couer þe mouþe of þe potte with parchemyne and sette it in a saue place.  fforsoþe if þou may [not?] haue flours of camamille in tyme of þi confeccion, þan in-stede of floure&yogh; tak M.i of þe tendre braunche&yogh; of camamille and putte þam with-out any brissyng in a potte, and putte oile ri&yogh;t hote vpon þam, as it is seid afore. And afterward when þou may haue flours of camamille, take þe forseid oile with þe braunche&yogh; of camamille and boile þam eftsone&yogh; vpon þe fire; and as it is seid afore, putte to a litel watre or elle&yogh; a litel vinegre, þat is better, þat þe oile may be more penetratyue, and boile it vnto þe wastyng of þe watre or of þe vinegre; and þat is knowen by boiling of þe oile made with noyse; þan cole it, and &yogh;ette it ri&yogh;t hote vpon þe floure&yogh; as it was seid.  Oile of camamille is temperate, and it is a blissyd þing of many helpyngs, and it is a conuenient resolutyue, and of akyng sedatyue, and it is prohibytyue of curse&yogh; of humours for a litel stiptikne&yogh; in it.  It comforteþ synowe&yogh; and al synuy membrye&yogh;; It helpeþ to þe akyng of þe heued, And generaly it availeþ to al akyng, and it is conuenient to al complexions, and it is ri&yogh;t subtile.  And als mych as it dissolueþ so mych consumeþ it.

6.0: 34. Of makyng of oyle of mastikk.
6.1: 34. [O]ile of masticus is made þus: Recipe Masticus ounce 1, thuris albi alexandrie ounce 1/2; be þai poudred & decocte in 1 lb. of oile of rose or of almande&yogh; or of note&yogh;; and when it is cocte yno&yogh;, cole it and kepe it to vse.  Þis oile helpeþ to euery akyng, of þe stomak, of þe iuncture&yogh;, of þe schuldre&yogh;, anoynted agayne&yogh; þe fire, and to akyng&yogh; of þe lyuer and of þe splene, putte to hote with lana succida.  It comforteþ vertu assimilatyue in a membre febled; wherfor it helpeþ to men in þe ethic, in þe ptisik, and disposed to þe lepre and to þe morfee, and to old men and consumed.  And anoynted it moisteþ þe skynne, and reuokeþ and restoreþ þe flesch consumed, and conforteþ þe stomak and makeþ it to diffy in cold cause; it represseþ þe abhominaciones of þe stomak, it giffeþ appetite, it scharpeþ þe mynde, It consumeþ al cold passions, It availeþ to hole men and to seke in al necessite&yogh;.  When þou wilt make þis oile agayn&yogh; þe vices of þe stomak, þan may þou make it with oile in which ar soþen som þings pertenyng to confortyng of þe stomak, as wormode, Mynt, Macis, galinga, & sich oþer, And so schal it better spede.

7.0: 35. Of makyng of oyle of almaunde&yogh;.
7.1: 35. [O]ile of almande&yogh; is made þus: Recipe amigdal. dulcis, old & no&yogh;t new, lb. 1/2, and tak of þe skynne&yogh; with hate watre; afterward brisse þam lang & wele without medlyng of any oþer þing; which y-brissed, be þai putte in a new strong bagge of lynne cloþe, and hyng þat bag ouer þe caldron or ouer a potte ful of boilyng water, so þat þe bagge touch no&yogh;t þe watre bot þat only it receyue þe fume of þe boilyng watre.  Afterward presse þe bag strongly and receyfe þe oile þat comeþ out and kepe it to þine vse.  Bot witte þou þat þis oile may no&yogh;t long endure.  It availeþ mych agayne brynnyng of vryne within in þe &yogh;erd, If it be cast in wyþ a syryng, And agayns oþer brennyng&yogh; also.

8.0: 36. Of makyng of water of almande&yogh;.
8.1: 36. [W]atre of almande&yogh; is made þus: Recipe almandes dulces clensed of þair skynne&yogh; and dryed, and brisse þam in a morter without medlyng of any oþer liquour; And after distille þam as þou distilleþ rose watre.  Þis availeþ agayn&yogh; brennyng of þe sonne in þe face, And also agayn&yogh; brynnyng in a manne&yogh; &yogh;erd, put in by a siryng.

9.0: 37. Of makyng of oyle of juniper.
9.1: 37. [O]ile of Iunipre is made þus: Recipe a new erþen potte, and putte it into þe erþe euen to þe mouþe; þan tak anoþer erþen potte whos bothme may be receyfed within þe mouþe of þe potte þat standeþ in þe erþe; And putte ane holowe canel of yren þur&yogh; þe bothme of þe ouer potte into þe neþer potte þat standeþ within þe erþe; þan tak dry stikke&yogh; of Iuniperi and kutte þam smal and putte þam into þe ouer potte, and þan lute þe mouþe&yogh; of boþe pottes with clay medled with horsdong. And make a fire al aboute þe ouermore potte, And þan scha[l] oile distille þur&yogh; þe canel into þe lawer potte, þe which kepe for þin vse, for it is ful noble for akyng.  It is gode for al maner goute and for þe parallesy.

10.0: 38. Of makyng of ane enoyntment of juniper.
10.1: 38. [A]lso ane enoyntment made of it to wonde&yogh; þat vnneþ bene curable and long tyme haue bene in þe bone&yogh;: Recipe fruyte of Iuniperi & fresch lard of a male swyne and brisse þam togidre; Afterward take 3 partes of ri&yogh;t strong white wyne and seþe þe forseid þing&yogh; in it, and when it is þikke sette doune fro þe fire.  And putte þerof to þe forseid sore&yogh; & wonde&yogh;.  It purgeþ, it filleþ, it heleþ & it cicatrizeþ.

11.0: 39. Of makyng of a gode emplastre for þe goute.
11.1: 39. [A] gode emplastre for þe goute: Recipe blak sope als mich as sufficeþ, to which putte als mych of raw &yogh;olke&yogh; of eyren as is half of þe sope, and medle þam strongly in a dish or in a box vnto þat þe sope lefe his owne colour; þe which y-done, putte it with þi fynger or with a spature vpon subtile stupe&yogh; of lyne and applie it faste vnto þe akyng place.  Aboue þis emplastre, forsoþe, putte a strictorie of white of eiren and mele of whete and lynnen cloute&yogh; y-dipped þerin, and putte it fast & applie it aboue þe forseid emplaster þat it be no&yogh;t remoued byfore dew tyme, bot if any competent cause aske it.  Þis medycyne is li&yogh;t but no&yogh;t litel effectual, þat haue I proued ofttyme&yogh;, als wele in wymen as in men; þat with one&yogh; puttyng to it ceseþ ful grete akyng&yogh; als wele in þe knee&yogh; as in þe fete and in oþer ioynture&yogh;; bot be-war þat it be no&yogh;t perceyued of þe pacient ne of none oþer; hold it pryuè and chere, and schew it no&yogh;t bot to þi son or ane als wele biluffed.  I trow, forsoþ, þat it availeþ bifor al oþer medicyne&yogh; to þe goute, and more sone abateþ þe akyng.  And it ow 5 daie&yogh; or 6 to lye stille without remeuyng if it may so bene applied.

12.0: 40. Of the properte of walwort & makyng of þe juse & poudre of it.
12.1: 40. [W]alwort "ebulus" is ane herbe like vnto el[d]re in lefe&yogh; and fruyte.  In odour it is sumwhat greuous and stynkyng. In tast it is as war bitter, bot in vertu anence old men it is deemed expert and effectuale, and kynde & free to medicyne in many vse&yogh;; witnesse plinius, diascoride&yogh;, macrobu&yogh; and many oþer, whos rote&yogh;, rynde&yogh;, and branche&yogh; and leue&yogh; and floure&yogh; bene profitable in medicyne&yogh;.  It haþe vertu of dissoluyng, consumyng of gret flemme and viscose with þe iuyse of it.  It availeþ agayn&yogh; þe gutte of þe ioynture&yogh; and contraccion of synue&yogh; of þe heude & of þe fete.  It availeþ also agayn&yogh; bolnyng&yogh; and collections intercutanie&yogh; wher-so-euer þai bene gedred in þe body. Also it availeþ most agayn&yogh; brissyngs of membre&yogh; and falle&yogh;, if þe membre&yogh; be fomented in his decoctions.  ffor why; it mitigateþ þe akyng, it ceseþ þe bolnyng, it ministreþ vertue and strength to synowe&yogh; and to ioynture&yogh;.  It availeþ agayne&yogh; bolnyng of þe womb of cold y-dropisy, if his Iuyse be dronken with hony and comyne.  And witte þou þat þe Iuyse of walwort, or þe poudre of it if it be hadde redy, is namely in euery medicyne þat is restrictyue of blode.  Þe maner of makyng and kepyng of it is as þe maner of licium seid afore.

0.0: 41. Of makyng of valence of scabious or mattefelon.
0.1: 41. Valence of scabious or of Iacee albe is þus made: Recipe Iuyse of scabious in somer, and cole it þur&yogh; a cloþe; and tak swyne&yogh; grese clensed of þe skynne&yogh; and stamp it wele in a morter in smytyng it bot no&yogh;t in brekyng vtterly; and euermore putte in a litel of þe iuyse to þe grese þat it may wele be imbibed and þat þe talow may be made grene; þe which y-done, tak þat grese and couer it with þe forseid iuyse and so late it stand 9 daie&yogh;.  And after 9 daie&yogh; take eftsone þe forseid grese with þe iuyse and stamp it as afore, and putte out þat þinne watryne&yogh; and discolored þat goþ out þerof, and so lat it stande 5 daie&yogh;. After þe 5 day eftsone tak new Iuyse of scabious and stamp it, as it is seid, with þe forseid grese; þe which y-done, latte it rest in a vessel with þe iuyse al a fourtny&yogh;t; which tyme ouerpassed, eftsone&yogh; bete it as it is seid afore, and purge it of þe watrine&yogh;, and putte it in a clene vessel, and lat it stand stil anoþer fourtni&yogh;t, And þan brisse it wele vnto þat it be al of grene colour.  And whan þe nedeþ for to vse þerof, as vnto þe antrax, putte þerof with þi fynger vpon clene stuppe&yogh; of lyne, and strech it and lay it on þe antrax anoynted with oile of rose, and remeued it no&yogh;t by a naturel day.  ffor without dout it schal slee þe antrax and swage þe akyng, and brist it and vtterly cure it.  And þis medyc[in]e is called Valence of scabious for þe valow of it.  It may be kepte many &yogh;ere&yogh;, bot it is better if it be euery &yogh;ere renewed and bette newly with oile roses, and putte vp agayne vnto it nede.  And witte þou þat scabious y-dronken sleeþ þe antrax, and putteþ away þe venym of it fro þe hert þat it sle no&yogh;t þe pacient.  Also þe same herbe ydronken turneþ inward aposteme&yogh; to outward and putteþ þam out insensibily. Also witte þou þat new scabious & fresch y-brissed with swynes grese and putte vpon antrax sleeþ it in a day naturel, and takeþ away þe akyng for certayne.  Bot for þat scabious may no&yogh;t euermore be had redy & fresch, þerfor was þis medicyne made þat may long be kept, þat wonderfully sleeþ þe antrax and vtterly cureþ it, as I haue proued myself ane hundreþ tyme&yogh;.  Also witte þou þat Iacea alba is scabious, bot Iacea nigra is matfelon.  And witte þou þat þat scabious þat groweþ among corne&yogh; with ane heuenly flour is better þan þat þat groweþ in mydowe&yogh; þat haþ no flour.  After diascorides trowe þou to þis þat it haþe no pere to þe forseid þing&yogh; wonderfully to be done, and þat softely.  I haue proued it a hundreþ tyme&yogh; for certayne.

1.0: 42. Of makyng of valence of wormode.
1.1: 42. Valence of wormode is þus made: Recipe iuyse of wormode, smalach, plantayn, and with swyne&yogh; grese clensed wele of þe skynne&yogh; brisse it wele and long togidre in maner as it is seid afore of þe valence of scabious; þe which y-done, kepe it to þin vse.  Þis valence of wormode availeþ to brissyngs of legge&yogh; and of schynbone&yogh;, and to wounde&yogh; þat ar made in þe muscle&yogh; of þe arme&yogh; and of þe legge&yogh; with a strey&yogh;t wounde, as of a knyfe or of ane arowe, PLATE IV.—From Sloane MS. 6, Brit. Mus., leaf 176, back. (1) A resonable gouernance of lawe&yogh; of lywyng. (2) Æsculapius helyd menne with &lbar;fernices & medicines. (3) Aschepius taught to geder rotes and herbe&yogh;, flowrie&yogh; and frote&yogh;. (4) Aschepius schewed mesures and quantitie&yogh;, weghte&yogh; and wares. (5) Aschepius techeth to make puluere&yogh; confeccionis & electuarie&yogh;. (6) Ypocras & galien schewe certeyne quantitie&yogh; iu preseruyng. or of sich oþer.  And it availeþ to al wounde&yogh; for to hold þam opne, and for certayne it mitigateþ wele þe akyng. When þe nedeþ for to vse þerof in wounde&yogh;, &yogh;ette in first of oile of rose&yogh; or of violet 2 droppe&yogh; or þre, and anoynt al þe wounde about of þe same oile&yogh;, and þe membre þat is hurt.  And afterward putte aboue of þe forseid valence vpon softe stupe&yogh; of lyne, and bynde it competently, and lat it so abide a naturel day.  Þis medicyne, forsoþ, represseþ wele bolnyng and akyng and holdeþ þe wounde opne, and gendreþ quitour, and draweþ out venym of þe wounde, and quencheþ þe brynnyng of þe membre.  Þis oyntment, forsoþ, luffed I mych; with þis medicyne cured I a fischer at london, which was hurt in þe lacert of his arme of þe prikkyng of a scharp yren standyng on þe gymewe&yogh; at þe frere Carome&yogh; cum hac medicina curavi quendam pistenarium apud London. qui ex puncturâ ferri acuti stantem super legimeus ad fratres Carmeli in lacerto brachii læsus . ; Wherfore he was almost dede, what of akyng, bolnyng, and brynnyng, and what of þe vncouenable cure of a barbour þat putte in þe wounde scharpe tente&yogh; of lynne cloþe, and putte aboue diaquilon.  His cure, forsoþ, remoued away, I putte to about euensang-tyme of þe forseid valence with anoyntyng of oile of roses, And bifore cokcrow þe pacient was delyuered of akyng and þe arme biganne for to swage, "vnbolne" and in the mornyng he sleped wele, and þe arme was purged of quitour by the wounde.  Bot witte þou þat I putte no tent in þe forseid wounde, bot al-only with &yogh;ettyng in of oile and puttyng aboue of þe valence without any-þing atuix I cured hym finaly; wherfor I gatte mych honour.  At nothyngham, forsoþ, I cured anoþer perfitely with þe forseid medicyne, þat was smyten in þe arme, bot no&yogh;t þorow, with a knyfe; of whos life men despaired for akyng and anguysch of þe pacient.

2.0: 43. Of makyng a man slepe without pulvere&yogh; or pille&yogh; or enoy[n]tement.
2.1:
43. Puluis for to make a man sleep agayn&yogh; his wille, after maner of Ribalde&yogh; and trowans in fraunce, þat felawshypeþ þam by þe waie&yogh; to pilgrime&yogh; þat þai may robbe þam of þair siluer when þai ar aslepe.  Recipe semen iusquiamus, &yogh;i&yogh;annie, i.[e.] darnel, papaueris nigri, i.[e.] chessede, de radice brionie sicc., ana; brek al-togidre in a brasen morter into ful smal poudre, of which poudre giffe hym in his potage or in a kake of whete or in drynk, & he 



 schal slepe alsone, wille he wil he no&yogh;t, al-aday or more after þe quantite þat he haþe taken.
2.2: Pillules for to prouoke slepe: Recipe amides dram j, croci dram iii, opii dram j; Make þam wyth watre of roses and make pillule ℞ Amidi &yogh;j: croci &yogh;iii: opii &yogh;i. Confice cum aquâ rosarum et pilulas dein de forma . and giffe þam; And he þat takeþ þam schal slepe for certayne. Ane vntement slepyng, with which if any man be anoynted he schal mow suffre kuttyng in any place of þe body without felyng or akyng.  Recipe succus iusquiami, Succus hyoscyami . Mandrage, Cicute, lattuce, papaueris albi & nigri, and þe sede&yogh; of al þise forseid herbe&yogh;, if þai may be hadde, ana; opii thebaici, opii Miconis ana, dram j or ij; fresch swyne&yogh; grese þat sufficeþ.  Breke al þise wele & strongly togidre in a morter, and afterward boile þam strongly and þan cole þam.  And if it be no&yogh;t þikke yno&yogh;, putte to a litel propoleos, i.[e.] white wex, and kepe it to þine vse.  And when þou wilt vse þerof, Anoynt his front, his pulse&yogh;, his temple&yogh;, his armehole&yogh;, and his lone&yogh; of his heud and his fete, and alsone he schal slepe so þat he schal fele no kuttyng. Unga frontem pulsus, axillas, volas manuum et plantas pedum et statim dormiet patiens nec incisionem sentiet Þis is also if a man may no&yogh;t slepe for oþer cause, as in febre&yogh; or sich oþer, for þis oyntment ouþer schal giffe hym remedy, or þe pacient schal die.  Also one grayne of opii thebaici to þe quantitè of dram ss., distempered with a pynte of wyne or more after þe mi&yogh;t of hym þat schal drynk it, scha&llbar; make hym þat drynkeþ it for to slepe.  Also þe sede alon of iusquiami albi giffen in wyne to drynk make þe drynker alsone for to slepe, þat he schal no&yogh;t fele what-so-euer is done to hym.  And þis proued I myself for certayne.  And witte þou þat it spedeþ for to draw hym þat slepeþ so by þe nose and by þe cheke&yogh; and by þe berde, þat þe spirite&yogh; be quickened þat he slepe no&yogh;t ouer ristfully. Also be þe lech warre þat he giffe no&yogh;t opium without croce for to drynk, for crocus and cassia lignea bene þe frene&yogh;, i.[e.] bridelle&yogh; of opii. Quia crocus et cassia lignea sunt fræna opii .

3.0: 44. Of þe maner of wakyng of hym.
3.1: 44. ffor to wake a man þat slepeþ þus: Putte to his nose gray brede y-tosted & wette in strong vinegre; or put vinegre or mustard in his nose; Or wasch his heued in strong vinegre; Or anoynt his temple&yogh; with þe iuse of  rubarb.  And giffe hym som oþer sternutorie&yogh;, and alsone he schal wake.  And witte þou þat it is gode for to giffe hym afterward castoreum, for it is triacle of iusquiamus theriaca hyoscyami . & opii & sich oþer, wheþer it be giffen in þe mouþe or in drynk, or it be put in þe nose; for castore chaufeþ & most conforteþ þe synewe&yogh; colded, and solueþ þe paralysye. And also giffe hym þat conforteþ þe brayne, as castore, nucis moschati, Myristicæ . roses, nenufare, mirtelle&yogh; & sumac.

0.1: Contra spasmum et crampe radix brionie in aqua cocta et postea pistata aut per se, vel in agrippa, vel oleo de semine lini, vel in dialthea, vel oleo de lilio aut camomille, collo emplastrata spasmum curat in quocunque membro corporis fuit.  Quia in collo est origo omnium morborum.  Et spasmus est contractio musculorum ad suas origines.  Istud carmen sequens contra spasmum expertissimum est a multis inventis eo utentibus, tam in partibus transmarinis quam in istis.  Nam apud mediolanis, i.[e.] Melane, in lumbardia tempore quo dominus Leonellus filius regis Anglie nupsit filiam domini Mediolani.  Anglici ibidem spasmo vexabantur propter potaciones vinorum fortium et calorum patriæ et nimium repletiones.  Unde quidam miles, et filius domini Reginaldi de Gray de Schirlond juxta Chestrefelde, qui fuit apud mediolanum cum domino leonello et habuit secum carmen sequens, et quemdam armigerum a spasmo vexatur ita quod caput suum retro trahebatur fere usque ad collum suum, ad modum balistæ , "crossbow" qui pro dolore et angustia fere exspiravit.  Quo viso, dictus Miles accepit carmen, in pergamento scriptum in bursa positum, in collo patientis apposuit dicentibus circumstantibus orationem dominicam ad dominam Maria[m] et, ut mihi juravit fideliter, infra quatuor horas aut quinque sanitati est restitutus. Et postea multos alios a spasmo ibidem liberavit, unde magna fama de illo carmine in illa civitate exercuit: Item in civitate Lincoln: … Item apud London: … Item apud villam de Huntingdon: … postea claudatur istâ cedulâ admodum unius litera ut non leniter possit aperiri, unde solebam scribere istud literis grecis, ne a laicis perspicietur . Quum ut istud carmen scriptum, se honeste in dei omnipotentis nomine gesserit et crediderit, sine dubio a spasmo non erit aggravatus.  Istud habeatur in reverentia propter dominum qui virtutem dedit verbis, petris et herbis, et secrete fingitur ne omnes nostant carmen ne forte virtutes datas a deo amittat.

1.0: A charm against Spasm and Cramp.
1.1: Bryony root boiled in water & afterwards crushed either by itself or in agrippa or in linseed oil or in dialthea or in oil of lily or camomile cures spasm when it is plastered upon the neck in whatever part of the body it may be.  Because the source of all diseases is in the neck: And spasm is a contraction of the muscles at their origin.  The following charm against spasm has been found most sovran by many who have used it both at home and abroad.  For amongst the Mediolani [i.e.] the Milanese, in Lombardy at the time when the Lord Lionel, son of the king of England, married the daughter of the lord of Milan, the English there were troubled with spasm due to their potations of the strong & hot wines of the country & to too many carouses.  Whereupon a certain knight, the son of Lord Reginald de Grey de Schirlond near Chesterfield, who was at Milan with the Lord Lionel & had with him the following charm, & saw a certain gentleman so troubled with the spasm that his head was drawn backward nearly to his neck just like a crossbow, & he was almost dead from the pain and starvation.  And when the said knight saw this he brought the charm written on parchment & placed it in a purse & put it upon the neck of the patient whilst those who stood by said the Lord's prayer and one to our lady Mary, and, as he swore faithfully to me, within four hours or five he was restored to health.  And afterwards he freed many there from spasm, & the great report of that charm spread throughout that state.  Again in the  city of Lincoln … again in London … again in the Town of Huntingdon.
1.2: In nomine patris ✗ et filii ✗ et Spiritus sancti ✗ Amen.
1.3: ✗ Thebal ✗ Enthe ✗ Enthanay ✗ In nomine Patris ✗ et Filii ✗ et Spiritus sancti ✗ Amen. ✗ Ihesu Nazarenus ✗ Maria ✗ Iohannes ✗ Michael ✗ Gabriel ✗ Raphael ✗ Verbum caro factum est ✗.
1.4: Let it be closed afterwards in the manner of a letter so that it cannot be opened easily, & for this reason I used to write it in greek letters that it might not be understanded of the people.  And if any one carries that charm written fairly in the name of God almighty, & believes, without doubt he will not be troubled with cramp.  Let it be held in respect on account of the Lord who gave virtue to words, to stones & to herbs, & let it be made secretly that every one should not know the charm lest perchance it should lose the virtues given by God.
